Journalistic Flashes
By Millard Langfeld

DOWN THE YEARS

more than 150 years ago a body of
determined, grim-lipped men gathered in a tiny
committee room atop old Independence Hall in Philadelphia. Meeting in secret session, many of them
not only lacking the support of the peoples they represented but the courage of their convictions as well,
they set about the stupendous task of saving a Union
dying before its life had scarce begun. Strained to
the breaking point by years of war and the inadequacies of the Articles of Confederation to band its
thirteen fragments together into a harmonious whole,
this New World infant offspring of Great Britain was
about to be destroyed by the enormity of its own
experiment.
And so for better than three months those men
met and labored in that little room above the chambers
where independence had been born. Of those labors
was born a plan, and of that plan a docume nt. And
through all the years that have since passed, that document, conceived in desperation and nurtured on sacrifice and hope, has proved the source and mainstay
of a mighty nation. For so our constitution came into
being.
Slightly more than a few months ago, another
group of grim lipped men, headed by a leader whose
courage and sincerity have proven him beyond reproach, took seats in Washington. They, too, faced
a desperate situation. They, too, had a desperate
answer. And so N. R. A. came into being.
And now it's up to us. Letting the other fellow
do the job won't get us anywhere. Nor will frenzied
zeal nor loud complaining. It has its faults. It works
some hardship, some injustice. It's oft times paradoxical. BUT IT'S A PLAN. AND PLANS,
NOT WORDS, ARE WHAT WE NEED.
And so it's up to us. Will we, as Americans, rise
to the challenge of the blue eagle and put our country
LIGHTLY

S

once more in the sun. Will we prove that jagged
emblem in his claws not a short circuit, but a lightning
bolt? God grant.

MURDER ON THE SHORE

A HOWLING, bestial mob went raging through
the streets of Princess Anne the other night, dragging
at the end of a fifty foot rope a Thing that once had
been a man. For better than a mile this calvalcade
of blood swept on, until it swung the naked form of
what remained at the noose's end high over the town.
And still they were not done. Still this mass of
humanity gone mad had not satiated its thirst for
gore. Back once more they stormed, to fill the main
streets of the village with the stench of burning flesh
from the carrion they had wrought. Like a demon
from a hellish,dream, a figure leaped about before the
flames, brandishing a severed ear.
This is no apology for Armwood—that is a chapter closed. If guilty, he deserved the utmost that the
law provides for wretches such as he. BUT THE
LAW, NOT CITIZENS TURNED MURDERERS
BERSERK! If the law acts too slowly, and it does;
if it allows glib shysters to play ducks and drakes
with justice, and it does; CHANGE THE LAW!
OUST THE SHYSTERS! But don't wade through
blood on the back trail to savagery.
o-OoSLIPPERY JAM!

"POLICE", reads an associated press dispatch
from Boston, "tie traffic up in jam as precaution while
money is moved." Reading on, we learn how Bay
City officers parked a moving van across a narrow
street for twenty minutes in the expectation the crowd
of excited motorists who soon blocked the street would
effectively prevent any attempted bandit get-away.
That's answering the motorist's prayer for downtown
parking with a VANgeance.

Among the staff members, Dean
Berry has been in Venezuela, Dr.
Cloos has been in the Sierra Nevadas of California, Dr. Donnay
has been in Belgium, and Dr. Singewalg was the leader of an excursion
of economic geologists made all
over the Southeastern part of the
United States.
In short, the geology men have
been working everywhere, for the
Department of Geology is one of
the most important parts of the institution, and the study of geology
is the pursuance of one of our most
valuable sciences. Geology has
opened up a world full of mystery
to our startled sight, a world of adventure and knowledge which has
compelled and will compel the attention of our greatest scientists for
all time.

A memorial meeting for Dr. Annabel Lee White, prominent educator who was a graduate of the Hopkins, will be held in Levering Hall
tomorrow at 3:30.
Among the well known speakers
who are scheduled to address the
meeting are Dr. David E. Weglein,
Superintendent of the Public
Schools of Baltimore; Glenn
Owens, principal of the Forest Park
High School; Dr. Ernest Becker,
principal of the Western High
School; and Dr. Florence E. Barnberger, professor of education at
the Hopkins.
Several musical selections will be
rendered by the Misses Elsie Craft
Hurley and Genevieve Butler.
At the time of her death in July
of this year, Dr. White was viceprincipal of the Forest Park High
School. She had taught in several
Baltimore public schools and was
former head of the mathematics department at the Western High
School.

Campus Brevities

Journalistic Flashes
By Millard Langfeld

DOWN THE YEARS

more than 150 years ago a body of
determined, grim-lipped men gathered in a tiny
committee room atop old Independence Hall in Philadelphia. Meeting in secret session, many of them
not only lacking the support of the peoples they represented but the courage of their convictions as well,
they set about the stupendous task of saving a Union
dying before its life had scarce begun. Strained to
the breaking point by years of war and the inadequacies of the Articles of Confederation to band its
thirteen fragments together into a harmonious whole,
this New World infant offspring of Great Britain was
about to be destroyed by the enormity of its own
experiment.
And so for better than three months those men
met and labored in that little room above the chambers
where independence had been born. Of those labors
was born a plan, and of that plan a docume nt. And
through all the years that have since passed, that document, conceived in desperation and nurtured on sacrifice and hope, has proved the source and mainstay
of a mighty nation. For so our constitution came into
being.
Slightly more than a few months ago, another
group of grim lipped men, headed by a leader whose
courage and sincerity have proven him beyond reproach, took seats in Washington. They, too, faced
a desperate situation. They, too, had a desperate
answer. And so N. R. A. came into being.
And now it's up to us. Letting the other fellow
do the job won't get us anywhere. Nor will frenzied
zeal nor loud complaining. It has its faults. It works
some hardship, some injustice. It's oft times paradoxical. BUT IT'S A PLAN. AND PLANS,
NOT WORDS, ARE WHAT WE NEED.
And so it's up to us. Will we, as Americans, rise
to the challenge of the blue eagle and put our country
LIGHTLY

S

once more in the sun. Will we prove that jagged
emblem in his claws not a short circuit, but a lightning
bolt? God grant.

MURDER ON THE SHORE

A HOWLING, bestial mob went raging through
the streets of Princess Anne the other night, dragging
at the end of a fifty foot rope a Thing that once had
been a man. For better than a mile this calvalcade
of blood swept on, until it swung the naked form of
what remained at the noose's end high over the town.
And still they were not done. Still this mass of
humanity gone mad had not satiated its thirst for
gore. Back once more they stormed, to fill the main
streets of the village with the stench of burning flesh
from the carrion they had wrought. Like a demon
from a hellish,dream, a figure leaped about before the
flames, brandishing a severed ear.
This is no apology for Armwood—that is a chapter closed. If guilty, he deserved the utmost that the
law provides for wretches such as he. BUT THE
LAW, NOT CITIZENS TURNED MURDERERS
BERSERK! If the law acts too slowly, and it does;
if it allows glib shysters to play ducks and drakes
with justice, and it does; CHANGE THE LAW!
OUST THE SHYSTERS! But don't wade through
blood on the back trail to savagery.
o-OoSLIPPERY JAM!

"POLICE", reads an associated press dispatch
from Boston, "tie traffic up in jam as precaution while
money is moved." Reading on, we learn how Bay
City officers parked a moving van across a narrow
street for twenty minutes in the expectation the crowd
of excited motorists who soon blocked the street would
effectively prevent any attempted bandit get-away.
That's answering the motorist's prayer for downtown
parking with a VANgeance.

Among the staff members, Dean
Berry has been in Venezuela, Dr.
Cloos has been in the Sierra Nevadas of California, Dr. Donnay
has been in Belgium, and Dr. Singewalg was the leader of an excursion
of economic geologists made all
over the Southeastern part of the
United States.
In short, the geology men have
been working everywhere, for the
Department of Geology is one of
the most important parts of the institution, and the study of geology
is the pursuance of one of our most
valuable sciences. Geology has
opened up a world full of mystery
to our startled sight, a world of adventure and knowledge which has
compelled and will compel the attention of our greatest scientists for
all time.

A memorial meeting for Dr. Annabel Lee White, prominent educator who was a graduate of the Hopkins, will be held in Levering Hall
tomorrow at 3:30.
Among the well known speakers
who are scheduled to address the
meeting are Dr. David E. Weglein,
Superintendent of the Public
Schools of Baltimore; Glenn
Owens, principal of the Forest Park
High School; Dr. Ernest Becker,
principal of the Western High
School; and Dr. Florence E. Barnberger, professor of education at
the Hopkins.
Several musical selections will be
rendered by the Misses Elsie Craft
Hurley and Genevieve Butler.
At the time of her death in July
of this year, Dr. White was viceprincipal of the Forest Park High
School. She had taught in several
Baltimore public schools and was
former head of the mathematics department at the Western High
School.
